Test Pre-Conditions:

Test Steps:

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Will this change affect the ldap server on the system controller?

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/te.message:
The manpage for nslcd.conf says this:
T<idle_timelimitT> SECONDS
Specifies the period if inactivity (in seconds) after which the connection to the LDAP server will be closed. The default is not to time out connections.

In addition to reducing the number of threads, I think we should look at setting this. Why do we need these connections to stay up forever? How often are the subclouds actually doing ldap queries?

I added 10 minutes inactivity timeout to close idle connections. However, there are suspicious ‘postgres’ login every 30 or 40 seconds which will keep the connections open. It should be looked at as a potential bug.

Agree, we should configure a timeout to close the idle connection.
The subcloud only performs ldap queries when there is a PAM use/group authentication request.
The default is now 2. Should this read 2 ?
The default here means it is set to 5 if 'threads' is not specified.
Recommend this be changed to the new default 600
Ok. The previous default is actually 0 (which disables this feature).

/COMMIT_MSG.message: nonexistent.
Done

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message:
is from_host a dictionary, and to_host an object?
both objects are accessing software_load attribute differently on this line, which is why I ask
Yeah it's a dict. A number of the upgrade functions are old/outdated. I may look to refactor them later in this release, but for now I'd like to limit the scope of the change.

sysinv/sysinv-fpga-agent/run_docker_logi.message: Don't we want this loop to exit after some timeout is reached? What is calling this and how would it react if this was to hang indefinitely?

docker login is expected to recover. If docker login is not recovered for whatever reason, the system is not functioning properly and the operations depend on the flag file won't proceed, exit or keep looping make very little difference. On the other hand, the log can provide helpful information for later troubleshooting to understand when or if docker login has ever recovered.
Hi Bin, in the scenario when it kept running for many minutes, was it the same error returned every time?

Puppet is invoking this as an exec and is running in the background, so will not be interrupted by the Puppet exec timeout.  I'm actually not sure what the behavior is if puppet exits before this is successful. Will it detach from the parent and keep running -- is this contributing to the root cause of the issue?
yes, it was the same error (authentication failed) repeated many times.

Yes it runs in the background detached from its puppet parent and it keeps running after puppet completes. In one test scenario it kept running many minutes after puppet completed and eventually successfully login docker and touched the flag file.

deployment/ovn/ovn-controller-container-.message: would it ever be desired to have this be configurable?

manifests/type/multi-tenant/shared/catal.message: Are these used by anything? They are technically covered by the worker node load balancer, loadBalancerWorker, which forwards traffic to the nodePorts. If they are not part of any substitutions to multiple places, I would recommend keeping them close to the LMA config.

The original idea was to put an exhaustive list in here (if I remember correctly!), but you're right that it's redundant with the load balancer range.

However, I'm still leaning toward
1) specifying them here
2) substituting them from this catalogue into the (lma-specific) resources that need them

Because: even though the undercloud doesn't care about the port elasticsearch is running on, it's very important to coordinate that port with the loadBalancerWorker range below.  For example we wouldn't want to change the nodePortRange and forget to change the elasticsearch port because it's "somewhere else" -- lumping all the ports into this one file is I think the most important thing about this file.

manifests/type/multi-tenant/sub-clusters.message: nit: this space was here to tie that note on L1 to the first two phases only. If you can find a clearer way to distinguish that, we would appreciate the improvement :)
Can you add this Phase definition to the type/sub-cluster/phases/phases.yaml?  It's basically a sister phase to plan "workload" -- workload deploys the operators, workload-config deploys the CRs.
This one is badly named and confusing -- it should be something like "vino-config".  Since we don't want to deploy/run vino *in* the subclusters, I think we should take this one out.
nit: I think we can save some confusion if we just leave this out. In the wordpress sub-cluster, there are no replacements and we forgo including an empty entrypoint.

Just FYI - I chatted with Drew, we want to remove this sub-cluster/workload entrypoint above, since
1) it's (intentionally) a no-op,
2) the convention for making a lma/workload phase entrypoint is already defined in type/sub-cluster/phases/phases.yaml.  So no real benefit to trying to use the no-op entrypoint as a convention-setter.

We'll follow up with a different change to remove the no-op entrypoint and true up the wordpress subcluster accordingly.
I think this is the right place for this and would still recommend removing it from the sub-cluster networking catalogue.
ha!  I would recommend substituting it into this resource!  Maybe we need a separate call to discuss pros/cons? :)

Ok Drew & I chatted and we are agreeing -- let's go with the way I described it, which will require creating a substitution rule to pull this port out of the subcluster-networking catalogue and put it into this resource.  You might add a comment here in this file along the lines of "this will get overridden via substitution from subcluster-networking catalogue" to avoid confusion.

The replacement rule will be specific to LMA (in the sense that it pulls from an LMA-specific path in the catalogue, and subs into this LMA-specific resource), and so should live in the type/sub-cluster/workload/replacements entrypoint I think.

Let me know if you'd like to talk through this!

Since this is LMA specific, did you mean to say it should live in the type/multi-tenant/sub-clusters/lma/workload/replacements directory?

I added a file there, lma-service-ports, that defines a replacementTransformer that pulls in these values from the subcluster-networking catalogue.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/ta.message:
you're collecting the cannical_hostname if cephadm_fqdn is true
or
you're collecting the inventory_hostname if cephadm_fqdn is false

In either case the loop is for members of the rbdmirror group.

The ansible bug would have me believe hostvars[item].variable might return undefined even if it isn't. In that case does this list builing task handle that? If not should we have an |default()? Or maybe an extra "when hostvars[item].canonical_hostname is defined"?

I don't remember exactly where we discussed about this part (it was probably somewhere in [1]), but I first created something like:

```
    - name: Collect the host and build the resulting host list
      set_fact:
        _hosts: "{{ _hosts|default([]) + [ hostvars[item].myhostnamevariable ] }}"
      with_items: "{{ groups['ceph_rbdmirror'] }}"
```

where 'myhostnamevariable' was either canonical_hostname (which is required for standalone deployments) or inventory_hostname according to the fqdn value.

However, the problem I found as per bug [2] is that the variable is never processed, and we always see the returned "AnsibleUndefined" string.
Adding a default('') doesn't help, because that part of the code is never reached (AnsibleUndefined is a string and it's always defined), that's why I didn't thought about adding a default() there.
It can be probably fixed later, but for now, I think leaving two tasks is fine, and we have control over it because we pass the tripleo_cephadm_fqdn boolean.
In any case it's something we can experiment with (and fix) in a follow up patch.
wdyt?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/773364
[2] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/68364

accessbot/channels.yaml.message:
Per discussion in yesterday's infra meeting, we're changing the channel move process for OFTC to clean up the old channel a while after it's no longer been in use. Please replace the entry here with a comment like:

  # - name: openstack-lbaas RETIRED 2021-06-02

This will be reflected in our documentation once Icbcc9b780ae3a2d1c19d2591158a9d36d0407582 merges.

Traditionally we've kept old channels registered and managed by accessbot, in order to reduce confusion in case someone else were to later re-register it, but that does also leave defunct channels litering the services database and is probably worth revisiting. I'll bring it up in the OpenDev sysadmins meeting today to see if we want to change that process at all.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/fi.message:
From what I can gather, etcd.conf is an INI-format config file, and should not be directly sourced in a bash script. If you're just looking to get the one variable, maybe try something like this:

IFS=', ' read -r -a URLS <<< $(awk -F '=' '/^ETCD_LISTEN_CLIENT_URLS/ {print $2}' ${ETCD_CONFIG_FILE} | tr -d '"')

if [ ${#URLS[8]} -le 0 ]; then
    logger "$0: ETCD_LISTEN_CLIENT_URLS not configured"
    exit 1
fi
Changes Done, I've only added a check for file existence
If this prevents the service from being launched, will this error be recorded anywhere? ie. will this be automatically logged by systemd? Or should this use "logger" instead?

If all you need to check is whether the url field is https, you don't need to source anything or set any vars. You could just grep the config file:
grep -q '^ETCD_LISTEN_CLIENT_URLS=.*\<https:' /etc/etcd/etcd.conf
HTTPS_LISTENER=$?
It is also used in the endpoints etcdctl flag

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
This is only for ipv4!
Furthermore, why you bind it to this IP as well? 
Can etcd listen on both IP? Have you tested it?

It works as well in IPv6. Loopback is written as ipv4 since the SAN list of the certificate has the 127.0.0.1 hard-coded

Regarding the second question, loopback ip is added since, bind_address gets the floating cluster address so yo ou can’t use that address to do the monitoring as it will result in SM thinking the service is active on both controllers.

It was tested and can listen correctly in both IP
should this be an IPv6 loopback address?

Loopback is written as ipv4 since the SAN list of the certificate has the 127.0.0.1 hard-coded. Regarding if it would work if the Ipv4 is between [], I've ran the following test prior the commit:

In wildcat-67 (Ipv6 lab) I've modified the etcd.pp adding 

$client_url = "https://[${bind_address}]:${port},https://[127.0.0.1]:${port}"

as in the current patch.

Afterwards I ran:

1- system service-parameter-add platform etcd bind_address="2620:10a:a001:a103::1033" --resource 'platform::etcd::params::bind_address'

(in order to re-apply the puppet and have the ipv4 loopback in it)

2- Lock and unlock the controller

3- checked the /etc/etcd/etcd.conf file and it has:
ETCD_LISTEN_CLIENT_URLS="https://[2620:10a:a001:a103::1033]:2379,https://[127.0.0.1]:2379"
ETCD_ADVERTISE_CLIENT_URLS="https://[2620:10a:a001:a103::1033]:2379,https://[127.0.0.1]:2379"

4- Checked the runnind etcd pid:
root      106051  0.0  0.0 113280  1208 ?        S<s  18:25   0:00 /bin/bash -c root      106052  0.3  0.1 12970848 69724 ?      S<l  18:25   0:02 /usr/bin/etcd --name=controller --data-dir=/opt/etcd/21.05/controller.etcd --listen-client-urls=https://[2620:10a:a001:a103::1033]:2379,https://[127.0.0.1]:2379 --client-cert-auth=true --trusted-ca-file=/etc/etcd/ca.crt --cert-file=/etc/etcd/etcd-server.crt --key-file=/etc/etcd/etcd-server.key

and it is running with both endpoints.

5- Ran the etcdctl to check health status:

sudo etcdctl --ca-file /etc/etcd/ca.crt -cert-file /etc/etcd/etcd-server.crt --key-file /etc/etcd/etcd-server.key --endpoints="https://[127.0.0.1]:2379" cluster-health

And it had a succesful response:

member 8e9e05c52164694d is healthy: got healthy result from https://[127.0.0.1]:2379
cluster is healthy
Hmm, really interesting.  Thanks for the test steps Jose

I'm guessing this works as it's reverting to IPv4 (and we should always have the loopback v4/v6 address on the loopback regardless of the IP version type of the system).  Does this also work if you do not include the square brackets around the loopback address?  It's just a bit confusing to see the IPv4 loopback enclosed in brackets typically used to denote an IPv6 address. Ideally you would use the IPv6 loopback address here.

Although not the same test the etcd stuff in this review, for interests sake I did a curl -vvv -g -6 http://[127.0.0.1]:8080/auth/login/?next=/  and while it does connect, a 400 bad request is returned.  curl -vvv -g -6 http://127.0.0.1:8080/auth/login/?next=/ and curl -vvv -g -6 http://[::1]:8080/auth/login/?next=/ return the login page

Does etcd do some sort of translation if it detects the loopback in this format?.  I was not aware this should be possible.  Are you definitely not able to use the IPv6 loopback address (::1) because of the comment you made earlier about the SAN list of the certificate?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is that going to cause problems during update/upgrade?

the ca itself won't change. it is just a different CA file location which gets bind mounted into the containers. if someone for whatever reason has specified a custom InternalTLSNbdCAFile, InternalTLSVncCAFile or InternalTLSQemuCAFile location we'd still use it. so it should not break updates.

deployment/nova/nova-vnc-proxy-container.message:
So, I understand what you're doing here in that we can avoid passing the cacert parameter to certmonger if we're using the default in any case - and avoid the problem altogether.

But I wonder if we can simplify further.  Is there a need for two different parameters - LibvirtVncCACert and InternalTLSVncProxyCAFile ?  Does the deployment make sense when these are different, given that LibvirtVncCACert defaults to InternalTLSVncProxyCAFile when not set?

Is it the case that LibvirtVncCACert is supposed to be used for the public interfaces and InternalTLSVncProxyCAFile for internal ones?

This patch is to address the default CA change for the existing releases where we manage the certs via puppet. Therefore my idea was to only do the necessary changes to have the new default and keep the other parameters as we likely can not just remove them?

To simplify the qemu/libvirt certs for the releases where we manage them in ansible I submitted
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/789718 . If we agree that we can backport a version of this to the previous releases with removing parameters I can work on that, what do you think?
Ok, sounds reasonable to do any the necessary for old releases just in case.  I think we definitely should consider removing parameters for wallaby.
thanks, sure, if you have time, please have a look at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/789718

nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.message: I guess if I had to fine one nit with this patch, it's that we're not asserting that we *haven't* added driver_iommu in cases when we shouldn't.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: Let's not debate whether this belongs in the main attach_volume(), or here. Both are fine, this is probably a tiny bit cleaner.
(But it definitely doesn't make sense to move this into the vif driver's get_config)

fwiw, I would have preferred to look over all existing devices later and just trigger _guest_configure_sev() instead of enabling IOMMU per device but I guess this sounds reasonable here at the least modified path.
here, surely we need to enable IOMMU on the fly per device, since it's a bind.
This is what's passed to get_updated_guest_xml as the get_volume_config() method, so I think you're good.

Right the issue was that it would then call this without instance below:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1a1a6a042c5b2295c7ab38b0387f3c234a704462/nova/virt/libvirt/migration.py#L211-L212

I'm not sure why this only failed in the LC job tbh but it should be resolved now, I'll also look at the above TODO this cycle.
Yup, only instance of a call to this API here

There are a couple of instances of this, but this is the only one that's relevant I think. The others are:

- for detach, from 'detach_interface': not relevant cos it's detach
- for PCI passthrough attach, from '_attach_direct_passthrough_ports': not relevant since these clearly can't be virtio devices
- for initial init, from '_get_guest_config': already handled via a later call to '_guest_configure_sev' in that method
- for live migration, from '_live_migration_operation': already handled via the later call to 'get_updated_guest_xml', which you've updated here
so in a follow up i want to move this call into the config generation in vif.py as i discussed with lee but for back porting i think we are ok with this. for now.

nova/virt/libvirt/migration.py.message:
*facepalm* Right, you meant the method signature.

As an aside, this kind of "hidden" coupling, where we're passing a method down but still expect the eventual caller to know its arguments is really ugly. I wonder if we could turn it into a functools.partial or something.
Yeah it's horrid and needs to be refactored, I was just going to generate the required volume configs in the driver and pass them down into this method tbh.

manifests/params.pp.message: This should NOT be updated, since this use pyvers instead of pyver3.

OK. I confirmed this behavior in Ubuntu20.04 at least.
As I mentioned in IRC, this should be a separate commit IMO. After  checking the actual behavior I feel this is a bug fix we should backport to older releases. (Maybe back to stable train which is the initial release with py3 support)

Hi Takashi,

We discussed this already, using a variable name for /usr/lib/python3 in Debian based OS is a mistake, because the Python modules are always stored in "python3" and not "python3.x". So I do believe my fix is correct.

No empty values are not getting ignored at this point, it get's added to DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF as an extra space, which with bash processing get's ignored as it runs "for file in $DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF", so i think it's fine.

'/etc/yum.repos.d/*-component.repo is not a valid yum repo configuration file.' is the error when component does not exist when the if statements are not included.
So far seems ok when the list item is empty.

container-images/tcib/base/os/cinder-bas.message: wouldn't it make more sense to add this as a dep to the cinder package?

I absolutely agree, and this is not the place to manage cinder's package dependencies. The correct place to do that (i.e. require libcgroup-tools) is [1].

[1] https://github.com/rdo-packages/cinder-distgit/blob/rpm-master/openstack-cinder.spec

In fact, many of the packages listed above can be pruned from the list because they're already pulled in by something else.
- nfs-utils, sysfsutils, targetcli (and a couple others) are pulled in by cinder itself (or pulled in indirectly via os-brick)
- libqb is pulled in by pacemaker

I'll try to clean this up in another patch.

manifests/params.pp.message: It should, there's no reason this should be a variable, the folder is *always* /usr/lib/python3 in Debian based systems.
Now I agree we should fix this but this should be fixed by a separate commit as I mentioned in the other patch.

roles/check_uc_hostname/tasks/main.yml.message:
This method of checking parameter_defaults works when tested on the undercloud - we just let the test PASS if DockerInsecureRegistryAddress is not found in /home/stack/containers-prepare-parameter.yaml

BUT - the molecule test for verifying failure breaks - since (for some reason) parameter_defaults[] is not being properly mocked from converge.yml

Like I said - this change fixes it running live on the box - but we need a way to mock things so that converge.yml can verify correctness and failure under molecule.

Looking for some help/suggestions...
Wouldn't that conditional be always true given the default, or am I missing something ?

I might be blind..but I can't really find where is this parameter_defaults variable defined, does the validation have knowledge of its existence? I guess you will need to check that DockerInsecureRegistryAddress is defined in teh containers file like you did here:       with_items: "{{ (lookup('template', '{{ check_uc_hostname_containers }}')
        | from_yaml).parameter_defaults.DockerInsecureRegistryAddress
        | list
        | first }}"

Another option would be calling: openstack stack environment show -f yaml qe-Cloud-0 and keep that in a parameters_defaults structure. The output of that command shows the values set during the overcloud upgrade prepare step.

parameter_defaults get defined /home/stack/containers-prepare-parameter.yaml

Assumption is customer follows: "Pinning container images for the undercloud assembly"

https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/16.1/html-single/director_installation_and_usage/index.html#ref_pinning-container-images-for-the\
-undercloud_assembly_performing-advanced-overcloud-container-image-management

which shows the command to run (which defaults to /home/stack as per documentation)

$ openstack tripleo container image prepare default \
  --local-push-destination \
  --output-env-file containers-prepare-parameter.yaml

Also - abandoning this patch - copied this exchange to not lose this comment.
All activity now documented and tracked at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-validations/+/796061

This is a valid way to get the undercloud_public_host, but maybe it's worth running the very same command we run in the suggested doc steps:
sudo hiera container_image_prepare_node_names

You could execute this in the undercloud (keep in mind the return is a list) and then make sure all of them are present in the DockerInsecureRegistryAddress.

yes - please see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-validations/+/796061 for changes to use 'hiera' command

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: can we assume there is no-one using a custom app?
If there are, it seems like a level of integration where they'd almost need to *expect* breakage with new versions, not unlike swift-on-file or something.

swift/container/reconciler.py.message: maybe a CONSTANT right up at the top?

right here we could (a) check the conf and raise exception or (b) fix the conf and write to a temp file or (c) fix the conf dict and have internal client optionally accept a conf dict rather than filepath...that avoids the subsequent plumbing to delegate the fix to the client which delegates to the proxy app

Seems like the sort of thing that'd require us to take on a lot of how paste turns a config into a wsgi app -- IIRC one of the advantages of modify_wsgi_pipeline is that it leverages paste to translate filter-name-in-pipeline (which we can't rely on) to entry-point-name (which we can), for example; IDK that I want to have to do that in Swift.

swift/proxy/server.py.message: it's always "interesting" how you can "bypass" the required/prohibited filters by changing filter names in the config

Well... kind of. filter_spec['name'] is actually the entry-point name, so even if you've got something like

 [pipeline:main]
 pipeline = ... dynamic_large_object ...

 [filter:dynamic_large_object]
 use = egg:swift#dlo

 ...

no proxy should add a second dlo. There's still the issue of name collisions across projects or (presumably; haven't tested this one) using

 paste.filter_factory = ...

lines, but it's actually more robust than I thought the first time I dug into it.

Shouldn't come up in practice (reconciler's the only guy that prohibits filters ATM, and it doesn't allow pipeline modifications), but this seemed the most reasonable way to handle it if it ever happens. I definitely *didn't* want to have a situation like

* operator configured a valid pipeline
* we automatically add a required filter
* we automatically remove it because it was also prohibited
* we report that the pipeline was modified when nothing changed.

test/probe/test_container_merge_policy_i.message: Note that this will come out None if encryption is not enabled -- and we'll assert that it's *still* None after it's moved to the other policy.

nice!  so we had a probetests for dynamic symlinks - but not for "hard" links

I guess we don't have one that explicitly enables encryption - you just have to turn on encryption (and put it in your internal_client.conf) and then run normal probetests?

Yup, that's what I'd done -- tweak my reconciler conf to have symlink, encryption, keymaster, etc. in the pipeline, then check that probe tests still pass.

The static symlink test came out of me playing with adding a ?symlink=get param to the reconciler -- that was enough to get the dynamic symlink test passing even with symlink in the pipeline. The more I played with scenarios in my head, though, the more I realized that we need to just exclude symlink similar to how we need to exclude encryption (albeit for different reasons) so I wrote a test to confirm it. Once I had the test, it seemed worth including it, even though I backed out the other approach I tried first.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I had to read the above multiple times before I understood it.

How about:

Linux kernel 5.10 requires a gcc version beyond 4.9 in order to build it.  So to build it we use a third party toolchain called devtoolset-8 which contains gcc version 8.3.  We only use this toolchain for the kernel and kernel modules, leaving the original gcc 4.8.5 in place for everything else.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/rehom.message: I don't see these being restarted in https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/stx-puppet/+/795113, are they handled implicitly somehow?  (Or maybe the naming is just not obvious...)

No, the restart of these services here are not necessary. Checked in sm-customer.log, with this commit, the restart of these two are not triggered after applying the manifest, the host-lock and service check can be still invoked.
does puppet-manifest-apply.sh make use of this parameter?  I dont see it treating it differently in the script than outside the 'ansible_bootstrap' or ' upgrade' case.

Yes, the "subcloud_rehome" will be parsed as a mainifest name in the script: https://github.com/starlingx/stx-puppet/blob/master/puppet-manifests/src/bin/puppet-manifest-apply.sh#L27. And this manifest will be expected to be applied same as the runtime manifest(without the extra runtime classes): https://github.com/starlingx/stx-puppet/blob/master/puppet-manifests/src/bin/puppet-manifest-apply.sh#L92-L172

puppet-manifests/src/manifests/subcloud_.message: As I didn't update the keystone password of vim during re-homing(it will be synchronized by DC orchestrator after managed), the re-apply of ::platform::nfv::api seems not required here. Is there a particular reason in your mind that it should be re-applied?
I was wondering as some host operations (e.g. host-lock) require api requests between sysinv, mtce and nfv.  However, I believe this may not apply in this rehome case.
is this new or was it being done under a different name in the ansible script previously?
separate chat with Yuxing indicates that we weren't properly restarting it previously, so this is a new thing.  Seems to make sense to do it, so I'm good.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: this seems like a lot of code duplicated from class platform::smapi above.  could we just include it and then add the service notification?
Yes, we can. The only difference is the ::platform::smapi::haproxy, which will request the haproxy classes. I'm trying to avoid it in order to get a "runtime" class for future usage
It would probably make sense to pull out the common bits into a separate class that can be included in both places.
If the haproxy values haven't changed, though, presumably including the class will result in no change made to the system.

tools/consistency.sh.message:
we also need to add plugins here:

```
DNSDIR=$(mktemp -d)
git clone https://opendev.org/openstack/designate-tempest-plugin $DNSDIR
ORCHESTRATIONDIR=$(mktemp -d)
git clone https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-tempest-plugin $ORCHESTRATIONDIR
SFSTDIR=$(mktemp -d)
git clone https://opendev.org/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin $SFSTDIR
```

if we export PYTHONPATH we don't have to write with every command plus we also need to include the plugins' locations:
export PYTHONPATH=$TEMPESTDIR:$DNSDIR:$ORCHESTRATIONDIR:$SFSTDIR

this will override returned code stored on line 27

Looking at the line 52 the idea behind these vars was to fail if any of them contains non zero value .. in order to do that the vars must be specific so that they don't override each other

let's name every exit_* var uniquely

let's also add the plugins' locations:
```
rm -rf $DNSDIR
rm -rf $ORCHESTRATIONDIR
rm -rf $SFSTDIR
```

if we name every exit_* var uniquely, we'll end up with:
```
(( $exit_1 || $exit_2 || $exit_3 || $exit_4 || $exit_4 || $exit_6 || $exit_7 || $exit_8 ))
```

Not sure the deprecation cycle applies here, the fact that kolla provides container images labeled as "binary" with software pulled via pip, curl, git, basically anything else than the distro package manager, is a bug. Do we need deprecation cycle for fixing bugs?

Perhaps we can add a "fake_binary" distro type for the transition, so folks may still have a way to build their "bogus" binary container images?

Sorry, not sure I understand how this info could be helpful
Mark for option list, see line 225, 233, 242, 257 and so on.
For us and other neutron developers or reviewers to have quick way to distinguish the option list for DHCPv6 we set.

consider refactoring to avoid code/logic duplication.
Or better just have a single method returning a tuple

According to coverage report actual indexes are not tested: https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_016/773283/22/check/openstack-tox-cover/016d940/cover/neutron_agent_l2_extensions_dhcp_ipv6_py.html

I would still prefer refactored version over duplication (and I don't see anything implicit there) + it will also reduce number of options iterations from 4 to 1
Done for the coverage.
why? please also check all below code comments, if they really help readability or the opposite
iterating through options 4 times while 1 iteration is enough
Done
Will add a TODO here, let's refactor it in a follow-up patch, since the stability of the current code is basically convergent.

I'm confused...:) Since you insist we should refactor the IA_NA opts methods. But it is stable enough with covered unit test cases. My idea is left as it is now, because:
1. the stability of the current code is basically convergent.
2. do not couple the code, since these methods are relatively new, not sure if somday one of those option methods will be changed based on some protocol clarification.
3. DHCPv6 options does not have tons of options, 4 times loop should not hurt the performance.

So, if you still insist to refactor these methods, IMO, let's do it in a follow-up patch. Because we will remove some methods with its correlative unit cases.
How would a follow-up patch ensure stability better than current patch? All this code is well covered with unit tests already

The reason is simple - I want to drive my review to the final +2, because I really like this feature and appreciate your efforts to opensource it. But I simply can't give a +2 on a code which I think must be refactored right away to avoid code duplication and redundant list iterations. I also think once code is well covered with unit tests (which is already done in this patch) - it should be safe to refactor + string parsing does not seem a very complex thing  to be refactored :)
Alright, let's start a new round review...

This should be "start is None and end is not None:".

All these if-else blocks are not human readable, I will add comments to each condition....
Looks a bit ugly, since every attributes are in coupled acquisition now. Nothing better than previous style.

consider making 'start' and 'end' required parameters, checks for None (which I believe you refer as ugly) won't be needed:

s[start:] === s[start:len(s)]
s[:end] === s[0:end]
But default IAID is one case rely on the start and end value.
Comments added for these conditions, and saving a loop for it, so let's leave it as it is.
I'd suggest to handle default IAID separately, not with _check_and_get_value
Done

neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovs_con.message: Should this be 'enable_ipv6'?  The other two had 'dhcp' in them in the spec too, but since they are in the [dhcp] section it implies they are for DHCP.

This has no effect on IPv6 availability otherwise, like operator can create subnet with ipv6 even if this is False?
I see this as controversial, as current dhcp-agent will serv dhcp if the subnet is IPv6 for the port.

Sorry, I'm afraid to say I get your real point. This option is for operators who want to disable the DHCPv6. Then this agent extension will skip some IPv6 related processing. For instance, some deployment may need user to config the IPv6 address inside the VM manually.

I have 2 concerns with this config option:
1.) this should be in the next patch (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/776567 )
2.) If I understand well currently I can set ipv6 address and mode (ra, slaac....) for the subnet on the API, this config option breaks that assumption, so I vote against it.

The DHCP agent extension only takes care of the DHCPv6 related requests, it is UDPv6 (with port 546/547). The RA related packet is based on ICMPv6. The RA and address_mode will no be influenced. The DHCPv6 request will be for address and other config options based on the "router" RA notification.

Relevant, but not the most important. This is a very common paradox. Such as, in API side, you create DVR router, but you have no agents set to "dvr" mode. You set enable_dhcp = True, but you have no running DHCP-agents. Operators should take care of the config differences between API and agents.
My concern is that the 2 different dhcp solution will work differently for IPv6.

1.) Make sense, I will move it.
2.) For some IPv4 only deployment, they may not need IPv6 related funtions. It's a simple option for DHCP extension to decide whether install the flows for port DHCPv6.

But then the API will behave differently in case distributed OVS based dhcp is used in a deployment.
Currently on the API there are flags for dhcp (like enable_dhcp, ipv6_address_mode, ipv6_ra_mode...) and with this config option the API will behave differently for "traditional dhcp-agent & dnsmasq" based neutron deployment and for distributed ovs-agent based deployment

playbooks/roles/nodepool-builder/templat.message: I've personally found docker's volume system to be annoying to use. You can't easily provision volumes out of different disks for example. I wonder if we shouldn't use /opt/nodepool_containers:/var/lib/containers instead to make this clear but also to take advantage of the large disk mount on /opt?

hooks/ceph_radosgw_context.py.message:
The commit that removed this support in Ceph [0] says support for PKI/PKIz are not supported since Ocata. Do we still support older-than-ocata releases? If not, we could simply this by dropping keystone_revocation_parameter_supported completely and unconditionally set 

rgw keystone revocation interval = 0

[0] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/27834

Yes billy, the option is non-existant from Octopus and so the logic. I am leaving the changes as it is.

Pon, hope billy's comment clarifies your question.
It does - thanks Billy, and Hemanth.

I'm okay with simplifying the logic and just hard coding the option. However, this sets it for the ceph radosgw itself which I believe was guarding against setting a non-existent option in the config file which is subtly different so I think the logic makes sense.

unit_tests/test_ceph_radosgw_context.py.message: Is there a reason you added this in the middle? It makes for some awkward organization of the code below where you're reading indices out of order. Its not incorrect, but the logical layout is a bit more confusing this way.

In hooks/ceph_radosgw_context.py IdentityServiceContext there are 3 cmp_pkgrevno functions in which 2nd one is introduced by this patch.
self.cmp_pkgrevno.side_effect expects 3 items in list one for each cmp_pkgrevno. Since the new one introduced is the 2nd one, new value is added in the middle. Hope this clarifies.

This can be avoided by moving the logic in hooks.ceph_radosgw_context.py as the LAST cmp_pkgrevno so that we can have minimal changes in the tests. Please let me know your opinion.

To me this is does not look like a role specific parameter[1]. How do you set it for CephStorage role with this?

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/train/deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-packages-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L50

nodepool/driver/azurestate/adapter.py.message: I always think about the pip tool when I read that. Maybe it would make sense to directly refactor those names to public_ipv4 and public_ipv6 to make this quicker to understand.

The pip4/pip6 is a huge change, it's used everywhere.  It doesn't bother me, and in fact, I like it, because there's so much boilerplate network stuff in azure that it's nice to abbreviate it.  But if you feel strongly about it, I'm willing to change.

But I'd like to do that after the end of the stack if that's okay (since it's a change with a large amount of textual conflicts and no functionality change).

I'm happy to add the initializers here.
self.pipx is not set in __init__ maybe it makes sense to add it there (and rename to public_ipv4/6 for better readability).
No it's fine, I guess I can adapt to this terminology ;)

doc/source/_exts/ansible-autodoc.py.message:
The single ' quotes can stay as they are.
I understand it's a stylistic choice, not a functional one.

But in general terms, I have often encountered notion that single quotes should be used for strings as keys or constants. While double quotes " should be used for human readable output.

Furthermore, changing all of the single quotes to doubles, noticeably bloats the patch and pollutes the diff.
Unintentionally reformatted my Emacs buffer with black, I guess…
We can use get method with default value here, relieve ourselves of conditional.

Merging the dicts is a good idea, although 'update' might be, slightly, more readable way to do that. But that's just my personal preference.

In any case. Merging the dictionaries would relieve us of all the conditions and get calls. Or most of them. So it has my vote.

I agree about that:

    provisioner_data = module_conf.get("provisioner",
                                       molecule_defaults.get("provisioner"))

or we could also merge the dicts and just refer to the new dict

    molecule_conf = {**molecule_defaults, ** molecule_conf}

This will create a new molecule_conf dict with the defaults getting overwritten by the current molecule_conf.
The quotes are a bit inconsistent here. Maybe we can put the strings into parentheses in a follow up patch.

pep8: F841 local variable 'in_payloads' is assigned to but never used
pep8: E501 line too long (81 > 79 characters)

We probably want to bump this up (or have a separate config value) as we reasonably expect these updates to take longer. Maybe something as simple as

 self.node_timeout * len(payload)

would work? Might want to cap it though :-/
We should only do this if we *don't* quarantine!
Should probably tolerate & ignore ENOENTs; see https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1877924

reference/sigs-repos.yaml.message: Seems the linter doesn't like this colon. Not sure what the proper format is though.
yeah, this is first time deprecation in sig repos. I need to modify the tooling for that to have this same format what we have for project team repo.

This is creating nested associative arrays, which doesn't match the existing schema at all (see how i18n adds an extra-atcs key to the array for the openstack/i18n repo by comparison).

You should either keep with the current schema since that's what tools parsing it expect, or switch to something which matches the projects.yaml schema (maybe with placeholder deliverable names) so that things like the election tooling can be simplified to only need one parser.

Yeah, what I meant by schema in this case is the data structure of the rest of the file. We parse this file in the election tooling to identify repositories for which we should include contributors in the rolls. What you had here would have broken the current election tools.

there is no schema for SIG team currently. issue here is we have splitted data for SIG in this file and in governance-sigs/sigs.yaml which we should combine and then have schema like project.yaml. I will work towards that.

meanwhile let me update it like i18n way.
